div.head: Report:
div.p: The experiment served three objectives. The first was to determine the quality of the crystal. The second was to determine the ds6 piezoelectric constant of KDP when approaching the phase transition temperature. The third was to turn the d36 piezoelectric constant into a temperature indicator.

At room temperature, the crystal proofed to produce nice diffraction profiles: the FWHM of the an electric field of 4.3~10~ V/m, was possible without inducing a significant current in the crystal. By applying a quasi-static electric field in the [00l] direction, the Bragg peak of a (hh0) reflection will seperate. One peak corresponds to the negative field, while the other corresponds to the positive field. The ds6 piezoelectric constant can be determined from the shift of the peak. At room temperature the shift was measured applying 5 different electric fields, corresponding to: 0, 250, 500, 750 and 1000 V. The expected linear relation between the shift and the electric field was found (figure l), indicating the good quality of the crystal. Furthermore, we measured the (hh0) and (h-ho) reflections, where h = -12, -10, .., 10, 12, in the presence of an electric field. The expected linear relationship between the shift of the peak and position of the peak, i.e. tan@, was found (figure 2), again indicating the good quality of the crystal. The slope of figure 2 is related to the da6 piezoelectric constant. The offset of the two datasets is, as expected, not zero and is related to the rigid rotation of the crystal. The ds6 piezoelectric constant at room temperature was found to be 20.9(3). from that measuring point, and since the sample was large, the exact temperature of the crystal might deviate from the measured temperature. sition point. As is obvious from figure 3, the peak of the (12 12 0) reflection at 129 K is seperated completely. The dss piezoelectric constant at the various temperatures can be determined. The result, given in figure 4, shows that the dse piezoelectric constant increases by one order of magnitude. Cooling down the crystal to 127 K (according to the cryostat) was straightforward. However, the way the crystal was mount limited the stress in the crystal (and thus the piezoelectric effect) and caused the crystal to crack at 125 K.

In combination with the data from Mason [l], the d3e piezoelectric constant was used to determine more accurate the actual temperature of the crystal. It turned out that 127 K according to the cryostat corresponds to 135.5 K according to Mason. This implies that we are still 12 K above the phase transition temperature. of temperature.
